app.domain.helpers package¶

Submodules¶

app.domain.helpers.enums module¶

Module with classes that inherit from python’s builtin Enum class.

class app.domain.helpers.enums.HttpCodes(value)[source]¶

Bases: enum.Enum

Enumerator class used to represent HTTP response codes

The following codes are considered:

  • DUMMY: Dummy value. Use when no valid HTTP code exists;

  • OK: Callee accepts the sent file;

  • BAD_REQUEST: Callee refuses the integrity of sent file;

  • NOT_FOUND: Callee is not a member of the network;

  • NOT_ACCEPTABLE: Callee already has a file with same Id;

  • TIME_OUT: Message lost in translation;

  • SERVER_DOWN: Metadata server is offline;

BAD_REQUEST: int = 400¶
DUMMY: int = -1¶
NOT_ACCEPTABLE: int = 406¶
NOT_FOUND: int = 404¶
OK: int = 200¶
SERVER_DOWN: int = 521¶
TIME_OUT: int = 408¶
class app.domain.helpers.enums.Status(value)[source]¶

Bases: enum.Enum

Enumerator that defines connectivity status of a network node

The following status exist:

  • SUSPECT: Network node may be offline;

  • OFFLINE: Network node is offline;

  • ONLINE: Network node is online;

OFFLINE: int = 2¶
ONLINE: int = 3¶
SUSPECT: int = 1¶

exception app.domain.helpers.exceptions.MatrixNotSquareError(value='')[source]¶

Bases: Exception

Raised when a function expects a square (N * N) matrix in any representation and some other dimensions are given.

app.domain.helpers.matlab_utils module¶

Module with Matlab related classes.

class app.domain.helpers.matlab_utils.MatlabEngineContainer[source]¶

Bases: object

Singleton class wrapper containing thread safe access to a MatlabEngine.

The purpose of this class is to provide a thread-safe way to access the matlab engine instance object when running simulations in threaded mode.

eng¶

A matlab engine instance object used for matrix and vector optimization operations throughout the simulations. Do not access this directly. MatlabEngine objects are not officially thread safe, thus it is recommended that you utilize the wrapped function, unless you are not running the hive_simulation with -t flag, i.e., you are not using the multithreaded mode to speed up simulations.

__LOCK = <unlocked _thread.RLock object owner=0 count=0>¶
__instance: MatlabEngineContainer = None¶
static get_instance() → app.domain.helpers.matlab_utils.MatlabEngineContainer[source]¶

Used to obtain a singleton instance of MatlabEngineContainer

If one instance already exists that instance is returned, otherwise a new one is created and returned.

Returns

A reference to the existing MatlabEngineContainer instance.

matrix_global_opt(a: numpy.ndarray, v_: numpy.ndarray) → Any[source]¶

Constructs an optimized transition matrix using the matlab engine.

Constructs an optimized transition matrix using linear programming relaxations and convex envelope approximations for the specified steady state v, this is done by invoke the matlabscript matrixGlobalOpt in the project folder name matlab.

Note

This function can only be invoked if you have a valid matlab license.

Parameters

  • a – A non-optimized symmetric adjency matrix.

  • v – A stochastic steady state distribution vector.

Returns

Markov Matrix with v_ as steady state distribution and the respective mixing rate or None.

app.domain.helpers.matrices module¶

Module used by domain.cluster_groups.Cluster to create transition matrices for the simulation.

You should implement your own metropolis-hastings or alternative algorithms as well as any steady-state or transition matrix optimization algorithms in this module.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.__get_diagonal_entry_probability(rw: numpy.ndarray, r: numpy.ndarray, i: int) → numpy.float64[source]¶

Helper function used by app.domain.helpers.matrices._metropolis_hastings() function.

Calculates the value that should be assigned to the entry (i, i) of the transition matrix being calculated by the metropolis hastings algorithm by considering the rejection probability over the random walk that was performed on an adjacency matrix.

Parameters

  • rw – A random_walk over an adjacency matrix.

  • r – A matrix whose entries contain acceptance probabilities for rw.

  • i – The diagonal-index of the random walk where summation needs to be performed on.

Returns

A probability to be inserted at entry (i, i) of the transition matrix outputed by the _metropolis_hastings function.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.__get_diagonal_entry_probability_v2(m: numpy.ndarray, i: int) → numpy.float64[source]¶

Helper function used by _metropolis_hastings function.

Calculates the value that should be assigned to the entry (i, i) of the transition matrix being calculated by the metropolis hastings algorithm by considering the rejection probability over the random walk that was performed on an adjacency matrix.

Parameters

  • m – The matrix to receive the diagonal entry value.

  • i – The diagonal entry index. E.g.: m[i, i].

Returns

A probability to be inserted at entry (i, i) of the transition matrix outputed by the _metropolis_hastings function.

app.domain.helpers.matrices._adjency_matrix_sdp_optimization(a: numpy.ndarray) → Optional[Tuple[cvxpy.problems.problem.Problem, cvxpy.expressions.variable.Variable]][source]¶

Optimizes a symmetric adjacency matrix using Semidefinite Programming.

The optimization is done with respect to the uniform stochastic vector with the the same length as the inputed symmetric matrix.

Note

  1. This function only works if you have a valid MOSEK license.

  2. The input Matrix hould have no transient states/absorbent nodes, but this is not enforced or verified.

Parameters

a – Any symmetric adjacency matrix.

Returns

The optimal matrix or None if the problem is unfeasible.

Builds a random walk matrix over the given adjacency matrix

Parameters

a – Any adjacency matrix.

Returns

A matrix representing the performed random walk.

app.domain.helpers.matrices._construct_rejection_matrix(rw: numpy.ndarray, v_: numpy.array) → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Builds a matrix of rejection probabilities for a given random walk.

Parameters

  • v – a stochastic desired distribution vector

  • rw – a random_walk over an adjacency matrix

Returns

A matrix whose entries are acceptance probabilities for the random walk.

app.domain.helpers.matrices._metropolis_hastings(a: numpy.ndarray, v_: numpy.ndarray, column_major_out: bool = True, version: int = 2) → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Constructs a transition matrix using metropolis-hastings algorithm.

Note

The input Matrix hould have no transient states/absorbent nodes, but this is not enforced or verified.

Parameters

  • a – A symmetric adjency matrix.

  • v – A stochastic vector that is the steady state of the resulting transition matrix.

  • column_major_out – optional; Indicates whether to return transition_matrix output is in row or column major form.

  • version – optional; Indicates which version of the algorith should be used (default is version 2).

Returns

An unlabeled transition matrix with steady state v_.

Raises

  • DistributionShapeError – When the length of v_ is not the same as the matrix a.

  • MatrixNotSquareError – When matrix a is not a square matrix.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.get_mixing_rate(m: numpy.ndarray) → float[source]¶

Calculats the fast mixing rate the input matrix.

The fast mixing rate of matrix M is the highest eigenvalue that is smaller than one. If returned value is 1.0 than the matrix has transient states or absorbent nodes.

Parameters

m – A matrix.

Returns

The highest eigenvalue of m that is smaller than one or one.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.is_connected(m: numpy.ndarray, directed: bool = False) → bool[source]¶

Checks if a matrix is connected by counting the number of connected components.

Parameters

  • m – The matrix to be verified.

  • directed – If the matrix edges are directed, i.e., if the matrix is an adjency matrix are the edges bidirectional, where false means they are.

Returns

True if the matrix is a connected graph, else False.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.is_symmetric(m: numpy.ndarray, tol: float = 1e-08) → bool[source]¶

Checks if a matrix is symmetric by comparing entries of a and a.T.

Parameters

  • m – The matrix to be verified.

  • tol – The tolerance used to verify the entries of the matrix (default is 1e-8).

Returns

True if the matrix is symmetric, else False.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.make_connected(m: numpy.ndarray) → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Turns a matrix into a connected matrix that could represent a connected graph.

Parameters

m – The matrix to be made connected.

Returns

A connected matrix. If the inputed matrix was connected it will remain so.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.new_go_transition_matrix(a: numpy.ndarray, v_: numpy.ndarray) → Tuple[Optional[numpy.ndarray], float][source]¶

Constructs an optimized transition matrix using cvxpy and MOSEK solver.

Constructs an optimized markov matrix using linear programming relaxations and convex envelope approximations for the specified steady state v. Result is only trully optimal if normal(Tranistion Matrix Opt - Uniform Matrix, 2) is equal to the markov matrix eigenvalue.

Note

This function only works if you have a valid MOSEK license.

Parameters

  • a – A non-optimized symmetric adjency matrix.

  • v – A stochastic steady state distribution vector.

Returns

Markov Matrix with v_ as steady state distribution and the respective mixing rate.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.new_mgo_transition_matrix(a: numpy.ndarray, v_: numpy.ndarray) → Tuple[Optional[numpy.ndarray], float][source]¶

Constructs an optimized transition matrix using the matlab engine.

Constructs an optimized transition matrix using linear programming relaxations and convex envelope approximations for the specified steady state v. Result is only trully optimal if normal(Tranistion Matrix Opt - Uniform Matrix, 2) is equal to the markov matrix eigenvalue. The code is run on a matlab engine because it provides a non-convex SDP solver ç BMIBNB.

Note

This function can only be invoked if you have a valid matlab license.

Parameters

  • a – A non-optimized symmetric adjency matrix.

  • v – A stochastic steady state distribution vector.

Returns

Markov Matrix with v_ as steady state distribution and the respective mixing rate.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.new_mh_transition_matrix(a: numpy.ndarray, v_: numpy.ndarray) → Tuple[numpy.ndarray, float][source]¶

Constructs a transition matrix using metropolis-hastings.

Constructs a transition matrix using metropolis-hastings algorithm for the specified steady state v.

Note

The input Matrix hould have no transient states or absorbent nodes, but this is not enforced or verified.

Parameters

  • a – A symmetric adjency matrix.

  • v – A stochastic steady state distribution vector.

Returns

Markov Matrix with v_ as steady state distribution and the respective mixing rate.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.new_sdp_mh_transition_matrix(a: numpy.ndarray, v_: numpy.ndarray) → Tuple[Optional[numpy.ndarray], float][source]¶

Constructs an optimized transition matrix using cvxpy and MOSEK solver.

Constructs a transition matrix using metropolis-hastings algorithm for the specified steady state v. The provided adjacency matrix A is first optimized with semi-definite programming techniques for the uniform distribution vector.

Note

This function only works if you have a valid MOSEK license.

Parameters

  • a – A non-optimized symmetric adjency matrix.

  • v – A stochastic steady state distribution vector.

Returns

Markov Matrix with v_ as steady state distribution and the respective mixing rate.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.new_symmetric_connected_matrix(size: int, allow_sloops: bool = True, force_sloops: bool = True) → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Generates a random symmetric matrix which is also connected.

See app.domain.helpers.matrices.new_symmetric_matrix() and py:func:app.domain.helpers.matrices.make_connected.

Args:
size:

The length of the square matrix.

allow_sloops:

See app.domain.helpers.matrices.new_symmetric_matrix().

force_sloops:

See app.domain.helpers.matrices.new_symmetric_matrix().

Returns

A matrix that represents an adjacency matrix that is also connected.

app.domain.helpers.matrices.new_symmetric_matrix(size: int, allow_sloops: bool = True, force_sloops: bool = True) → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Generates a random symmetric matrix.

The generated adjacency matrix does not have transient state sets or absorbent nodes and can effectively represent a network topology with bidirectional connections between network nodes.

Args:
size:

The length of the square matrix.

allow_sloops:

Indicates if the generated adjacency matrix allows diagonal entries representing self-loops. If false, then, all diagonal entries must be zeros. Otherwise, they can be zeros or ones.

force_sloops:

Indicates if the diagonal of the generated matrix should be filled with ones. If false, valid diagonal entries are decided by allow_self_loops param. Otherwise, diagonal entries are filled with ones. If allow_self_loops is False and enforce_loops is True, an error is raised.

Returns

The adjency matrix representing the connections between a groups of network nodes.

Raises

IllegalArgumentError – When allow_self_loops (False) conflicts with enforce_loops (True).
